commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

commit_message:
Select policy when running functional test

Add ability to select a storage policy when running
the functional tests by defining the environment variable
SWIFT_TEST_POLICY.

This patch was first introduced by Janie Richling in
feature/ec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/166097

Co-Authored-By: Janie Richling <jrichli@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Christian Schwede <christian.schwede@enovance.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kota Tsuyuzaki <tsuyuzaki.kota@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistair.coles@hp.com>

Change-Id: Id96354546088df137def0ae7fd434baf64ed0c51
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add worlddump unit test

Add a worlddump unit test to avoid simple breakages

Change-Id: I6b87d4dbe22da2c1ca5ceb13134e9bb570f5cef2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/05/197305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Simple test of worlddump.py TOP=$(cd $(dirname "$0")/.. && pwd) source $TOP/tests/unittest.sh OUT_DIR=$(mktemp -d) $TOP/tools/worlddump.py -d $OUT_DIR if [[ $? -ne 0 ]]; then fail "worlddump failed" else # worlddump creates just one output file OUT_FILE=($OUT_DIR/*.txt) if [ ! -r $OUT_FILE ]; then failed "worlddump output not seen" else passed "worlddump output $OUT_FILE" if [[ $(stat -c %s $OUT_DIR/*.txt) -gt 0 ]]; then passed "worlddump output is not zero sized" fi # put more extensive examination here, if required. fi fi rm -rf $OUT_DIR report_results

commit_message:
Lower log level for extending network/subnet/port

These extensions are too normal and happens lots, So there is
no need to use info level.

Change-Id: Ic6700bc1874efff8e7ecb63fe6d6c7151578e64d
Closes-bug: 1473859

Unconditionally running this can lead to confusing failure output from

Change-Id: I37cb84fe8e0b393f49b8907af16a3e44f82c46a6
"}]
commit_message:
Check for nova-compute before running kill

Unconditionally running this can lead to confusing failure output from
kill as the pgrep matches nothing when nova-compute isn't yet running.

Change-Id: I37cb84fe8e0b393f49b8907af16a3e44f82c46a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/04/197304/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: subprocess.check_call(["pgrep","nova-compute"]) except subprocess.CalledProcessError: print "Skipping as nova-compute does not appear to be running" return

commit_message:
Improve description of "parameters" and "template" params

Change-Id: Ic97a87c3021d6e843ce6dea1bb10299b6811b7d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/76/202276/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The files parameter maps logical file names to file contents. These are used by the get_file intrinsic function as well as the provider template functionality. When you want to use a provider template, for example, Heat will actually add an entry to the files map using the URL of the provider template as the "name" and the contents of that file as the value. Additionally, some template authors will encode their user-data in a local file. The Heat client will examine the template for the get_file intrinsic function and add an entry to the files map with the "path" to the file as the name and the file contents as the value. So, a simple example might look like the following: "template": "(...) resources: my_server: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: user_data: { get_file: myfile } "files": { "myfile": "#!/bin/bash echo 'Hello world' > /root/testfile.txt" }

commit_message:
Volume manager should set filter_function and goodness_function

If a user defines a filter_function or goodness_function in their cinder.conf
file the scheduler should use that function. This change appends those
functions to volume_stats if the driver has not specified them.

Change-Id: I76f90aa3c1bda7564185d8e130926af7d0827e0e
Closes-Bug: #1458061
(cherry picked from commit cbc708b13982bc11eb4956c9f3f1f96f009dafff)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/99/201299/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(vol_manager.VolumeManager, 'update_service_capabilities') def test_report_filter_goodness_function(self, mock_update): manager = vol_manager.VolumeManager() manager.driver.set_initialized() myfilterfunction = "myFilterFunction" mygoodnessfunction = "myGoodnessFunction" expected = {'name': 'cinder-volumes', 'filter_function': myfilterfunction, 'goodness_function': mygoodnessfunction, } with mock.patch.object(manager.driver, 'get_volume_stats') as m_get_stats: with mock.patch.object(manager.driver, 'get_goodness_function') as m_get_goodness: with mock.patch.object(manager.driver, 'get_filter_function') as m_get_filter: m_get_stats.return_value = {'name': 'cinder-volumes'} m_get_filter.return_value = myfilterfunction m_get_goodness.return_value = mygoodnessfunction manager._report_driver_status(1) self.assertTrue(m_get_stats.called) mock_update.assert_called_once_with(expected)

Use message for DeviceNotFoundOnAgent

commit_message:
Add v1 quota tests in-tree

Change-Id: I77a9038b81f01f9d85f20d4e2ad5cbe182a86da3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/53/191153/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import six from tempest_lib.common.utils import data_utils from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.api.v1 import base from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.lib import test class QuotasTest(base.BaseAdminNetworkTest): """ Tests the following operations in the Neutron API using the REST client for Neutron: list quotas for tenants who have non-default quota values show quotas for a specified tenant update quotas for a specified tenant reset quotas to default values for a specified tenant v2.0 of the API is assumed. It is also assumed that the per-tenant quota extension API is configured in /etc/neutron/neutron.conf as follows: quota_driver = neutron.db.quota_db.DbQuotaDriver """ @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(QuotasTest, cls).skip_checks() if not test.is_extension_enabled('quotas', 'network'): msg = "quotas extension not enabled." raise cls.skipException(msg) @classmethod def setup_clients(cls): super(QuotasTest, cls).setup_clients() cls.identity_admin_client = cls.os_adm.identity_client def _check_quotas(self, new_quotas): # Add a tenant to conduct the test test_tenant = data_utils.rand_name('test_tenant_') test_description = data_utils.rand_name('desc_') tenant = self.identity_admin_client.create_tenant( name=test_tenant, description=test_description) tenant_id = tenant['id'] self.addCleanup(self.identity_admin_client.delete_tenant, tenant_id) # Change quotas for tenant quota_set = self.admin_client.update_quotas(tenant_id, **new_quotas) self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.reset_quotas, tenant_id) for key, value in six.iteritems(new_quotas): self.assertEqual(value, quota_set[key]) # Confirm our tenant is listed among tenants with non default quotas non_default_quotas = self.admin_client.list_quotas() found = False for qs in non_default_quotas['quotas']: if qs['tenant_id'] == tenant_id: found = True self.assertTrue(found) # Confirm from API quotas were changed as requested for tenant quota_set = self.admin_client.show_quotas(tenant_id) quota_set = quota_set['quota'] for key, value in six.iteritems(new_quotas): self.assertEqual(value, quota_set[key]) # Reset quotas to default and confirm self.admin_client.reset_quotas(tenant_id) non_default_quotas = self.admin_client.list_quotas() for q in non_default_quotas['quotas']: self.assertNotEqual(tenant_id, q['tenant_id']) @test.idempotent_id('a7add2b1-691e-44d6-875f-697d9685f091') @test.requires_ext(extension='lbaas', service='network') def test_lbaas_quotas(self): new_quotas = {'vip': 1, 'pool': 2, 'member': 3, 'health_monitor': 4} self._check_quotas(new_quotas)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-07 16:04:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/987fcc28991c0f39d983b55d391399b9109fd0b7', 'message': "Fix 'no actual-pathname' NetApp API error

commit_message:
Fix 'no actual-pathname' NetApp API error

Cinder volume logs sometimes show this error

      NetApp API failed. Reason - 13114:
      No actual-pathname for 10.1.0.9:/vol/whatever

with Kilo code and 7-mode DOT system.

The issue is due to our Cinder driver passing the
entire share to the relevant API instead of just
the export path portion of the share.  This only
happens when the NFS image cache is full, and cached
files need to be removed.

Change-Id: I0c40840dac975dd7fd2c62f1f9c0cd3f8c5c1252
Closes-Bug: #1468884
(cherry picked from commit 6a65422c69bd5f2fc363238b2383b66aab575272)

commit_message:
Pin os-brick to the current release

This will protect projects using os-brick for now
to the existing release.  We want to release new
versions of os-brick in the near future, but force
that update through CI.

Change-Id: Ie456bb8c5d91bf5e0dd979d15a79af3ed991136d

commit_message:
workaround: l3 plugin misses dvr_deletens_if_no_port method

Although dvr_deletens_if_no_port isn't part of l3 interface,
it's a part of dvr l3 plugin because ml2 plugin calls the method on
l3 plugin. It causes following exception when deleting network.

TODO:
This patch only addresses AttributeError exception so that some tempest
tests pass. Later the method needs to be implemented meaningfully
in order to support dvr.

> Exception during message handling: 'OpenDaylightL3RouterPlugin' object has no attribute 'dvr_deletens_if_no_port'

> executor_callback)

> result = func(ctxt, **new_args)
> File "/odl/neutron/neutron/api/rpc/handlers/dhcp_rpc.py", line 170, in release_dhcp_port
> plugin.delete_ports_by_device_id(context, device_id, network_id)
> File "/odl/neutron/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py", line 884, in delete_ports_by_device_id
> self.delete_port(context, port_id)
> File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_db/api.py", line 146, in wrapper

> removed_routers = l3plugin.dvr_deletens_if_no_port(
> AttributeError: 'OpenDaylightL3RouterPlugin' object has no attribute 'dvr_deletens_if_no_port'

Change-Id: I3f24df4e99a3df6d968480172f8e31fce119533f
Closes-Bug: #1474265

commit_message:
IS_GATE should be disabled by default, set to True in devstack/pre_test_hook.sh

Change-Id: Ie6db108ca3412e12b570fe25428eea38087b26f3

commit_message:
Migrate compute tests to the ssh-auth-strategy

Migrate the compute tests to the new ssh-auth-strategy format.

Partially implements: blueprint ssh-auth-strategy

Change-Id: I69ef7ba6e245d8d88f0a059115a0a232f0d46c31

commit_message:
ramdisk: enable ppc64 support for symlink

Patch enables symlink /usr/lib -> ../lib  support for ppc64 Fedora deployment ramdisk.

Change-Id: I01994685292d7c1cae0f9ec1a1052d68420b4b82
Closes-Bug: #1463357

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-16 15:17:35.000000000', 'files': ['glance/tests/unit/async/flows/test_import.py', 'glance/tests/unit/v2/test_tasks_resource.py', 'glance/tests/unit/async/test_taskflow_executor.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/899a8b9a77766505ad9002c543576af0f1db9a74', 'message': "Remove usage of assert_called_once in mocks

This was never a real part of the mock api, but mock was happily mocking
it out and letting the tests pass. The new mock release made this
behaviour break, causing tests to fail on all patches. This patch
replaces instances of assert_called_once with an assert of the mock's
call_count.

Closes-Bug: #1473369
Co-Authored-By: Ian Cordasco <graffatcolmingov@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit df0e566f2a144f53df77be29abb1f02ff11cf9be)

commit_message:
Remove usage of assert_called_once in mocks

This was never a real part of the mock api, but mock was happily mocking
it out and letting the tests pass. The new mock release made this
behaviour break, causing tests to fail on all patches. This patch
replaces instances of assert_called_once with an assert of the mock's
call_count.

Closes-Bug: #1473369
Co-Authored-By: Ian Cordasco <graffatcolmingov@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit df0e566f2a144f53df77be29abb1f02ff11cf9be)

Conflicts:
	glance/tests/unit/async/test_taskflow_executor.py

Change-Id: I12ff85a9480d8000b0de54939c3be71458162a40
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/39/202639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: get_task_factory = mock.Mock() mock_get_task_factory.return_value = get_task_factory get_task_factory.new_task.return_value = new_task new_task.run.return_value = mock.ANY get_task_executor_factory = mock.Mock() mock_get_task_executor_factory.return_value = get_task_executor_factory get_task_executor_factory.new_task_executor.return_value = mock.Mock() get_task_repo = mock.Mock() mock_get_task_repo.return_value = get_task_repo get_task_repo.add.return_value = mock.Mock() self.assertEqual(1, get_task_factory.new_task.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, get_task_repo.add.call_count) self.assertEqual( 1, get_task_executor_factory.new_task_executor.call_count)

commit_message:
Heat could not create samples with Ceilometer

Heat could not create samples with Ceilometer, because ceilometer client has
change some key words in CREATION_ATTRIBUTES which is using by create sample.

Change-Id: I8e8dc80ae1b666ae74e2b2c2b757e7f468c25de2
Closes-Bug: #1455421
(cherry picked from commit e4eeeed95a748715dac3a1752f82875966820c6d)

commit_message:
go: fix expect 100-continue in replicator

Sort of.  I mean it's not ideal, but it's probably better than it was.
We might switch to some non-HTTP protocol for replication later, since
we can design it to better deal with the information flow.

Change-Id: I4571e3dc08a81c3712e1e5c5e97f3578a2ea1465
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/90/201690/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // Copyright (c) 2015 Rackspace // // Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); // you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. // You may obtain a copy of the License at // // http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 // // Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software // distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, // WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or // implied. // See the License for the specific language governing permissions and // limitations under the License. package hummingbird import ( "bufio" "io" "net" "net/http" "net/http/httputil" ) // ExpectTransport is an http.RoundTripper that supports Expect: 100-Continue. // Nobody is happy that this exists. Hopefully it will go away after Go 1.6. type ExpectTransport struct { Dial func(network, addr string) (net.Conn, error) DisableCompression bool // for compat sake, we don't use it. } // RoundTrip performs an HTTP request, returning the response and error. func (t *ExpectTransport) RoundTrip(req *http.Request) (*http.Response, error) { if req.Body != nil { defer req.Body.Close() } requestHeaders, err := httputil.DumpRequestOut(req, false) if err != nil { return nil, err } dial := t.Dial if dial == nil { dial = net.Dial } conn, err := dial("tcp", req.URL.Host) if err != nil { return nil, err } if tcpConn, ok := conn.(*net.TCPConn); ok { tcpConn.SetNoDelay(true) } if _, err := conn.Write(requestHeaders); err != nil { conn.Close() return nil, err } reader := bufio.NewReader(conn) if req.Header.Get("Expect") == "100-Continue" { resp, err := http.ReadResponse(reader, req) if err != nil { conn.Close() return nil, err } if resp.StatusCode != 100 { resp.Body = &responseBody{ReadCloser: resp.Body, conn: conn} return resp, nil } } if req.Body != nil { if _, err := io.Copy(conn, req.Body); err != nil { conn.Close() return nil, err } } resp, err := http.ReadResponse(reader, req) if err != nil { conn.Close() return nil, err } resp.Body = &responseBody{ReadCloser: resp.Body, conn: conn} return resp, nil } func (t *ExpectTransport) CancelRequest(req *http.Request) { // TODO(redbo) } type responseBody struct { io.ReadCloser conn net.Conn } // Close closes the response body, and either closes the underlying connection or returns it to the pool. func (r *responseBody) Close() error { r.ReadCloser.Close() r.conn.Close() return nil }

commit_message:
go: adding middleware & routing framework

Add middleware & routing framework for hummingbird

It allows hummingbird to statically chain middlewares to both object & proxy server.
It also adds a routing library written by the patch co-author.

Change-Id: Iaa4d1e8c72caff554a86dbf638077483dfb4ebc7
Co-Authored-By: Michael Barton<mike@weirdlooking.com>

added_lines: // Copyright (c) 2015 Rackspace // // Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); // you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. // You may obtain a copy of the License at // // http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 // // Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software // distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, // WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or // implied. // See the License for the specific language governing permissions and // limitations under the License. package middleware import ( "net/http" "github.com/openstack/swift/go/hummingbird" ) func ValidateRequest(next http.Handler) http.Handler { fn := func(writer http.ResponseWriter, request *http.Request) { if !hummingbird.ValidateRequest(request) { hummingbird.StandardResponse(writer, 400) return } next.ServeHTTP(writer, request) } return http.HandlerFunc(fn) }

Data model updates for active/standby lb topology

1. Create value tables for: lb topology, and amphora roles.
2. Add a topology column to the load_balancer table.
3. Add a role column to the amphora table.
   topology can take values: SINGLE, ACTIVE_STANDBY
   role can take values: STANDALONE, MASTER, or BACKUP.

commit_message:
Remove p26 job from DIB

It's time to stop supporting py26 - our tests are failing on it due to
mock no longer supporting py26 and there are other breaking changes
incoming in the near future.

Change-Id: If8ce8fd85742f7e7d4fb2bacad21d1f9a2531ed7

commit_message:
Add unit tests and fixes for OVS Agent QoS Extension Driver

Add basic unit tests and fix some of the issues while doing
the tests

blueprint ml2-ovs-qos-with-bwlimiting

Change-Id: I3962dd2c0e1273905781faf3f5c51886dea21cd4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/83/201583/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from neutron.extensions import qos from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.openvswitch.agent.extension_drivers import ( qos_driver) from neutron.tests.unit.plugins.ml2.drivers.openvswitch.agent import ( ovs_test_base) class OVSQoSAgentDriver(ovs_test_base.OVSAgentConfigTestBase): def setUp(self): super(OVSQoSAgentDriver, self).setUp() self.qos_driver = qos_driver.QosOVSAgentDriver() self.qos_driver.initialize() self.qos_driver.br_int = mock.Mock() self.qos_driver.br_int.get_qos_bw_limit_for_port = mock.Mock( return_value=(1000, 10)) self.qos_driver.br_int.del_qos_bw_limit_for_port = mock.Mock() self.qos_driver.br_int.create_qos_bw_limit_for_port = mock.Mock() self.rule = self._create_bw_limit_rule() self.port = self._create_fake_port() def test_create_new_rule(self): self.qos_driver.br_int.get_qos_bw_limit_for_port = mock.Mock( return_value=(None, None)) self.qos_driver.create(self.port, [self.rule]) call_counts = self.qos_driver.br_int.call_count # Assert create is the last call self.assertEqual( 'create_qos_bw_limit_for_port', self.qos_driver.br_int.method_calls[call_counts - 1][0]) self.assertEqual(0, (self.qos_driver.br_int ).del_qos_bw_limit_for_port.call_count) (self.qos_driver.br_int.create_qos_bw_limit_for_port ).assert_called_once_with(self.port['name'], self.rule['max_kbps'], self.rule['max_burst_kbps']) def test_create_existing_rules(self): self.qos_driver.create(self.port, [self.rule]) self._assert_rule_create_updated() def test_update_rules(self): self.qos_driver.update(self.port, [self.rule]) self._assert_rule_create_updated() def test_delete_rules(self): self.qos_driver.delete(self.port, [self.rule]) (self.qos_driver.br_int.get_qos_bw_limit_for_port ).assert_called_once_with(self.port['name']) (self.qos_driver.br_int.del_qos_bw_limit_for_port ).assert_called_once_with(self.port['name']) def test_unknown_rule_id(self): self.rule['type'] = 'unknown' self.qos_driver.create(self.port, [self.rule]) self.assertEqual(0, (self.qos_driver.br_int ).create_qos_bw_limit_for_port.call_count) self.assertEqual(0, (self.qos_driver.br_int ).del_qos_bw_limit_for_port.call_count) def _assert_rule_create_updated(self): call_counts = self.qos_driver.br_int.call_count # Assert create is the last call self.assertEqual( 'create_qos_bw_limit_for_port', self.qos_driver.br_int.method_calls[call_counts - 1][0]) (self.qos_driver.br_int.get_qos_bw_limit_for_port ).assert_called_once_with(self.port['name']) (self.qos_driver.br_int.del_qos_bw_limit_for_port ).assert_called_once_with(self.port['name']) (self.qos_driver.br_int.create_qos_bw_limit_for_port ).assert_called_once_with(self.port['name'], self.rule['max_kbps'], self.rule['max_burst_kbps']) def _create_bw_limit_rule(self): return {'type': qos.RULE_TYPE_BANDWIDTH_LIMIT, 'max_kbps': '200', 'max_burst_kbps': '2'} def _create_fake_port(self): return {'name': 'fakeport'}

commit_message:
Use shared shell arguments provided by Session

The cinderclient implemented it's own version of the CLI arguments that
are now provided by keystoneclient's session object. This changeset
converts cinder over to utilizing the shared argument registration.

Closes-Bug: 1434105
Change-Id: I72b16aab909d72a47097434436093e616667634a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/33/165833/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Register the CLI arguments that have moved to the session object. session.Session.register_cli_options(parser) parser.set_defaults(insecure=utils.env('CINDERCLIENT_INSECURE', default=False))
deleted_lines: parser.add_argument( '--os-cert', metavar='<certificate>', default=utils.env('OS_CERT'), help='Defaults to env[OS_CERT].') parser.add_argument( '--os-key', metavar='<key>', default=utils.env('OS_KEY'), help='Defaults to env[OS_KEY].') parser.add_argument( '--os-cacert', metavar='<ca-certificate>', default=utils.env('OS_CACERT', default=None), help=_("Specify a CA bundle file to use in " "verifying a TLS (https) server certificate. " "Defaults to env[OS_CACERT]")) parser.add_argument('--insecure', default=utils.env('CINDERCLIENT_INSECURE', default=False), action='store_true', help=argparse.SUPPRESS)

commit_message:
Remove dict assumption from remotable decorator

The remotable decorator still has code that assumes we can use dict-like
accesses on our objects. This converts it to a setattr.

Change-Id: I45c6e3e9e7bde343a67aa3dfdbb3787b21641cd5
Closes-Bug: #1474952
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects refs/changes/00/202200/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self[key] = value else: self[key] = field.from_primitive(self, key, value)

commit_message:
VM up/down status metrics, other libvirt changes

This change is mostly about adding metrics for VM up/down status,
but also adds some documentation and other minor libvirt-related tweaks:

* Added aggregate metrics to the documentation for VM monitoring
* Removed 'cloud_tier' dimension; it was used by TripleO, and is no longer necessary
* Added host_alive_status for inactive VMs
* Added ping check for active VMs
* Added gathering of private_ip for each instance (necessary for ping checks)
* Added detection of the correct ping command to the libvirt detection plugin
* Placeholder for future libvirt metrics

Change-Id: I02ac24090b5eeb305522dc7d80162d576d263a55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/50/200750/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os import subprocess# List 'ping' commands (paths and parameters) in order of preference. # The plugin will use the first fuctional command. 127.0.0.1 will be appended. ping_options = [["/usr/bin/fping", "-n", "-c1", "-t250", "-q"], ["/sbin/fping", "-n", "-c1", "-t250", "-q"], ["/bin/ping", "-n", "-c1", "-w1", "-q"]] agent_user = 'monasca-agent' # Verify functionality of the ping command to enable ping checks for ping_cmd in ping_options: if os.path.isfile(ping_cmd[0]): with open(os.devnull, "w") as fnull: # Build a test command that uses sudo and hits localhost ping_local_cmd = ["sudo", "-u", agent_user] ping_local_cmd.extend(ping_cmd) ping_local_cmd.append("127.0.0.1") try: res = subprocess.call(ping_local_cmd, stdout=fnull, stderr=fnull) except subprocess.CalledProcessError: pass if res == 0: log.info("\tEnabling ping checks using {0}".format(ping_cmd[0])) init_config['ping_check'] = " ".join(ping_cmd) break if 'ping_check' not in init_config: log.info("\tUnable to find suitable ping command, disabling ping checks.") init_config['ping_check'] = 'False'

commit_message:
EMC ScaleIO Data Client Shim Libvirt Volume Driver

This specification proposes to add a shim libvirt volume driver for
the support of ScaleIO Data Client (SDC) connected volumes. The
addition of SDC support to libvirt will be leveraged by Nova to
attach/detach volumes provided by EMC ScaleIO. This shim driver
will be based on os-brick.

DocImpact
Implements blueprint emc-sdc-libvirt-volume-driver

Change-Id: Idc7191b4f9af069fb018260d07dc58c67f675351
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/41/181941/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== EMC: ScaleIO Data Client (SDC) Libvirt Volume Driver ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/emc-sdc-libvirt-volume-driver This blueprint proposes to add a libvirt volume driver for the support of SDC (ScaleIO Data Client) connected volumes. The addition of SDC support to libvirt will be leveraged by Nova to attach/detach volumes provided by EMC ScaleIO. Problem description =================== This blueprint is submitted for the ScaleIO Cinder driver. The blueprint for the Cinder driver is here: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/scaleio-cinder-volume-driver In order to support mounting ScaleIO block volumes to Nova instances, a libvirt volume driver for ScaleIO block protocol is needed. This blueprint proposes to add such a driver to Nova. Proposed change =============== A libvirt volume driver for the ScaleIO protocol used by EMC ScaleIO will be added to the nova/virt/libvirt directory. A section will be added to the list of libvirt volume drivers in the file nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py. This will direct volumes of 'volume_driver' type 'scaleio' to the correct driver. A new module called 'scaleio.py' will be introduced. This module will contain all the code related to scaleio. There will be minimal changes to volume.py. Refer to the description of ScaleIO technology at: http://www.emc.com/storage/scaleio/index.htm ScaleIO is software-only server based SAN technology. It allows the use of commodity disks to deliver affordable and scalable block storage. To use this driver, the user has to install additional component: * The SDC Linux driver This software can be downloaded from the following web site for free: http://www.emc.com/storage/scaleio/index.htm Once these dependencies are met, and this driver is installed, Nova nodes can mount block volumes from ScaleIO and use them just like any other block storage. The SDC Linux driver will direct storage traffic over TCP/IP to the right server. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- End users will be able to create block volumes from ScaleIO and use them in OpenStack. This change is accompanied by a Cinder driver for EMC ScaleIO. Performance Impact ------------------ This technology takes advantage of massively parallel I/O processing, with all servers participating and sharing I/O loads. By adding servers, you can increase capacity and processing power linearly, leveraging fast parallel rebuild and rebalance without interruption to I/O. Other deployer impact --------------------- The ScaleIO SDC component must be installed on the OpenStack compute node. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: xing-yang Other contributors: lital Work Items ---------- * ScaleIO Libvirt volume driver -- this is already developed * An entry in the volume.py file * a filter for scaleio in nova/rootwrap Dependencies ============ Cinder blueprint for EMC ScaleIO driver, already approved for Liberty-1: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/scaleio-cinder-volume-driver Testing ======= A 3rd party CI system is being set up to test the Cinder driver. Documentation Impact ==================== This needs to be documented as a new driver. References ========== Cinder ScaleIO driver blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/scaleio-cinder-volume-driver EMC ScaleIO: http://www.emc.com/storage/scaleio/index.htm

commit_message:
Use proper status code for partial content

Glance v2 previously handled requests to download the image with Range
headers properly but did not set the correct status code per RFC 7233.
A request like:

    GET /v2/images/image-uuid
    Host: glance-api:9292
    Range: bytes=1024-4098

Should see a response like

    HTTP/1.1 206 Partial Content
    Content-Length: 3074

APIImpact
DocImpact

Closes-bug: 1399851
Depends-On: I76fd3746a2c449e257ea2a19c2dc6118be207eec
Change-Id: Ic741328855e6871e0c567db435bf928b6013a2a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/75/139775/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: response.status_int = 206

commit_message:
Change group controller of V2 test cases

The existing controller didn't change V21's controller makes
the whole test focus on V21 instead of V2.

commit_message:
WIP - Ironic-Neutron Integration

Please do not review - this is a POC only
This patch exhibits the way to pass Ironic specific
infomation into neutron so that it can be consumed
by ML2 Plugin and pushed down to registred ML2
mechanism drivers.

Change-Id: I08107e099201b6e6fdd3350b8d8836607a952c80

commit_message:
update to 0.2.5 of the magic search widget

Update the XStatic Magic Search package, to take
advantage of Eucalyptus' new fixes and features.  Including
allowing multiple Magic Search widgets on same page.

Change-Id: I1328ed868d1278d5cd631bcddcc0c2ba924e65b1
Partial-Bug: #1434710

Change-Id: I0b960f999a9e52880450a5c18f7f88119be41566
'}]
commit_message:
policy: Dynamic Policies Overlay

Adds to ``oslo.policy`` the capability to overlay
rules in policy file with custom rules received
as a regular Python dict.

This feature will be used by Keystone Middleware
in the context of ``Dynamic Policies``, which
will fetch the custom policy rules from Keystone
server and ask ``oslo.policy`` to do the overlay
processing, i.e write them to the policy file.

Partially-Implements: bp dynamic-policies-delivery

Change-Id: I0b960f999a9e52880450a5c18f7f88119be41566
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/53/196753/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. ========================== Dynamic Policies Overlay ========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo?searchtext=dynamic-policies-overlay ``Dynamic Policies`` (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/DynamicPolicies) aims to improve access control in OpenStack by improving the mechanisms in which policies are defined and delivered to service endpoints. One step of dynamic delivering of policies is to overlay the existing service endpoint's local policy file with the custom rules defined in Keystone. This overlay task is delegated to ``oslo.policy``. Problem description =================== Alice the Cloud Deployer ------------------------ Alice is the kind of person who loves new features and eagerly awaits for new OpenStack features like ``Dynamic Policies`` to enable them in her cloud. With that feature, she expects to be able to define her custom policy rules in Keystone and have those applied to service endpoints transparently. Behind the scenes, Keystone Middleware will fetch the custom policy rules for the service it is serving and ask ``oslo.policy`` to overlay the existing local policy file with them. Proposed change =============== Based on a dict containing rules and on the existing options ``policy_file`` and ``policy_dirs``, add to ``oslo.policy`` the capability to overlay rules in the existing local policy file. Alternatives ------------ Make Keystone Middleware itself overlay the existing local policy, however it seems to not be a task for it at all, since ``oslo.policy`` is the one which does handle policy files and owns the config options defining where such file is placed. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None Security impact --------------- This change touches policy rules, which are sensitive data since they define access control to service APIs in OpenStack. Performance Impact ------------------ None Configuration Impact -------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Testing Impact -------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Samuel de Medeiros Queiroz - samueldmq Other contributors: Adam Young - ayoung Morgan Fainberg - mdrnstm Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Liberty-2 Work Items ---------- * Create a new function that receives as input a python dict containing custom policy rules and write them out to the local policy file, using override strategy when local rules when a clashing occurs. Incubation ========== Adoption -------- Any service using the ``Dynamic Policies`` mechanism for access controll will be using the proposed change through Keystone Middleware, which means that adoption is transparent to services. Library ------- The proposed change will affect the ``oslo.policy`` library. Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None Documentation Impact ==================== None besides the regular Python code level documentation. Dependencies ============ - Related to spec 'Fetch policy.json from server' (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/134655/), which defines how the custom rules will be fetched and cached by Keystone Middleware and then passed to the proposed ``oslo.policy`` call; - Relared to spec 'Policy by URL' (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/192422/), which specifies how policy custom rules are associated to a service endpoint in Keystone server. References ========== None .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Use bool_from_string in oslo.utils

oslo.utils provides a function in strutils to convert strings to
boolean values. We should be using this instead of reinventing the
wheel.

Change-Id: I127207cf4e2c04ede4899f710f144b03eb79e00b

commit_message:
Retry ipmi commands unless the failure is not retriable

Consider that image deployment is a time-consuming operation, most
ipmi failures worth retrying, even when BMC is temporarily offline.
List keywords of error messages in configuration file, ipmi commands
will be aborted if runtime error messages match keywords, otherwise
will be retried.

Closes-Bug: 1474953
Change-Id: Ib9e8c319070d0a509ea672f34d908afad84a2387

commit_message:
Retry ipmi commands unless the failure is not retriable

Consider that image deployment is a time-consuming operation, most
ipmi failures worth retrying, even when BMC is temporarily offline.
List keywords of error messages in configuration file, ipmi command
will be retried if runtime error message does not match keywords.

Change-Id: If42f8996eb3973aa2a2e845387a92fab5863c08b
Closes-Bug: 1474953

commit_message:
Update Magic Search to 0.2.5

Update the XStatic Magic Search package, to take
advantage of Eucalyptus' new fixes and features.  Including
allowing multiple Magic Search widgets on same page.

commit_message:
Change Dockerfile to use Debian as a base

Ubuntu licensing does not allow for distributing derivatives of Ubuntu,
including containers based on Ubuntu. We currently publish a CoreOS PXE
image with an IPA container embedded. Basing this container on Ubuntu
appears to violate Ubuntu's license. Let's move to Debian to fix this.

Also remove the python3 purge as python3 doesn't exist in the Debian
base image.

Closes-Bug: #1475325
Change-Id: I051e3123f0cd1e66b5e3bae727559fe31467791b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/78/202578/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: FROM debian:jessie

commit_message:
Python 3: Replacing unicode with six.text_type for py3 compatibility

The "unicode" type was renamed to "str" in Python 3.
Use six.text_type to make swiftclient compatible with Python 3.

For more information about changes needed for py3
compatibility, see:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

Change-Id: Ic65607a69935652a1874340928f626fbcc35c014

commit_message:
Allow subcommands to accept --help when using 'deferred_help'.

This patch changes how cliff handles help for subcommands but only when
'deferred_help' is enabled. Currently cliff consumes --help requests at the top
level. This means `myapp foo --help` and `myapp --help` produce the same output.
To get help for `foo` one must use `myapp help foo`. With this change
`myapp foo --help` will produce the same output as `myapp help foo` by
transforming the --help request into a help subcommand one. This is only done
when there are any options on the command line other than --help. When a top
level --help is requested the original behavior of print_help_if_requested()
is preserved.

Change-Id: I628bbfc383de516045288512cc023213d723a027
Closes-Bug: 1444983
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cliff refs/changes/58/201258/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_subcommand_help(deferred_help=False): app, _ = make_app(deferred_help=deferred_help) if deferred_help: # Show that provide_help_if_requested() did not show help and exit with mock.patch.object(app, 'run_subcommand') as helper: app.run(['show', 'files', '--help']) helper.assert_called_once_with(['help', 'show', 'files']) else: # Help is called immediately with mock.patch('cliff.help.HelpAction.__call__') as helper: app.run(['show', 'files', '--help']) assert helper.called def test_subcommand_help(): _test_subcommand_help(False) def test_deferred_subcommand_help(): _test_subcommand_help(True)

commit_message:
add post-stack script callout

After the main stack.sh is called, provide the ability for a
post-stack script to be called. This can assist in supporting
multinode testing.

Change-Id: I42c2d8ae88a5abe871f286eb9f59b320376056f4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/73/199073/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ -e $GRENADE_DIR/post-stack.sh ]]; then cd $GRENADE_DIR ./post-stack.sh stop $STOP post-stack.sh 15 fi

commit_message:
Modal service is incorrectly named

Currently, the simple modal service is named "modal.service.js". This is
incorrect, the file name should be "simple-modal.service.js".
Also fixed linting issues.

Why do we care about a rename?
Leaving it as is leaves room for naming collision.
We will likely introduce other modal services in the near future
(for example, the wizard-modal.service)

Change-Id: I61b9c93f37adf0004e99970cf9194ba4fd22eb00
Closes-Bug: #1475046
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/28/202328/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * 'horizon.framework.widgets.modal.simple-modal.service' .factory('horizon.framework.widgets.modal.simple-modal.service', modalService);
